questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding mosquitoes?

choices.text: It is the definitive host in malaria
Mansonia is a vector for Malayan filariasis
Life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
All mosquitoes can travel only for 100 metres

questions.solution:
Most mosquitoes can travel or fly for distances up to 11 kms.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

Characteristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia

Eggs: 100-250. 

 Laid singly. Boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star-shaped clusters.

Larval stage

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to the undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Striped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artificial collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis, Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 

Called Nuisance mosquitoes

These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called tiger mosquitoes

Day biters

They get the tiger's name from the white stripes on its legs.

 Big, black, or brown mosquitoes with sparkling wings and legs. 

 

 

Culex mosquito keeps their bodies horizontal while feeding.

 Anopheles mosquito tends to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high.

Aedes mosquito has a striped body pattern.

questions.text: Which of the following species of mosquitoes breed in dirty water and water bodies containing aquatic vegetation respectively?
questions.solution:
Culex species of mosquitoes breed mostly in dirty and polluted water. Mansonia species of mosquitoes breed in water bodies containing aquatic vegetation.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about larva of mosquitoes?

choices.text: Culex larva lies in water with head faced downwards
Anopheles larva lies parallel to the undersurface of water

questions.solution:
Anopheles larva has no siphon tube as shown in the image below.

The image given below shows Culex larva having a siphon tube.

questions.text: Identify the species of mosquito shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The given image is of an Aedes mosquito.

They can be identified with the stripes on the legs and body. They are also called tiger mosquitoes because of their stripes.

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady from a tribal area presented with fever, chills, vomiting, and abdominal pain for 4 days. The peripheral smear of the patient is given below. Which of the following is true about the mosquito which transmits this disease?

choices.text: Keeps its body horizontal while feeding

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and peripheral smear showing ring form/ early trophozoites in erythrocytes are suggestive of Plasmodium falciparum malaria. It is transmitted by Anopheles mosquitoes. They have spotted wings.

They breed in clean water. Their larva has no siphon tube and lies parallel to the undersurface of water. They tend to sit with their heads low and their rare ends raised high, especially when feeding.

questions.text: A patient presented with fever, headache, and retro-orbital pain for 3 days. He tested positive for the NS1 antigen. Which of the following mosquitoes transmits the disease he's suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the positive NS1 antigen test is suggestive of dengue fever. It is transmitted by the Aedes mosquito, which is also called as tiger mosquito.

questions.text:
Which of the following diseases is not transmitted by Aedes mosquito?
  1. Chikungunya
  2. Yellow fever
  3. Japanese encephalitis
  4. Rift valley fever
  5. West Nile fever
questions.solution:
Japanese encephalitis and West Nile fever are transmitted by Culex mosquitoes.

Chikungunya, yellow fever, and rift valley fever are transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes.

questions.text: A banker who is scheduled to travel to Congo is advised to take the yellow fever vaccine. What is the flight range of the mosquito which transmits this disease?
questions.solution:
Yellow fever is transmitted by the Aedes mosquito. Its flight range is 100 metres.

questions.text: A patient with fever and mucosal bleeding is diagnosed with dengue fever. Which of the following is false about the mosquito which transmits this disease?

choices.text: Development of larva from egg does not require water
It has a striped body pattern

questions.solution:
Dengue fever is transmitted by the Aedes mosquito. The conversion from the egg stage to the larval stage of this mosquito requires water.

Eggs of any mosquito species do not survive without water. But the eggs of Aedes mosquitoes lie dormant in dry conditions for up to about nine months. They can hatch if exposed to favourable conditions such as water and food.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the OPD with complaints of fever and headache for 5 days. Serological examination shows the presence of IgM antibodies to the JE virus. Which of the following mosquitoes transmits this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Japanese encephalitis. It is transmitted by Culex mosquitoes like Culex tritaeniorhynchus

questions.text:
Match the following diseases and the mosquitoes which transmit them.
Disease Mosquito
l.Yellow fever a.Mansonia
ll.Bancroftian filariasis b.Aedes
lll.Malaria c.Culex
iV.Malayan filariasis d.Anopheles

choices.text: l - c, ll - a, lll - d, iV - b
l - a, ll - b, lll - c, lV - d
l - b, ll - c, lll - d, lV - a
l - d, ll - a, lll - b, lV - c

questions.solution:
The correctly matched diseases with the mosquitoes which transmit them are:

Disease Mosquito
Yellow fever Aedes
Bancroftian filariasis Culex
Malaria Anopheles
Malayan filariasis Mansonia

questions.text: Which of the following is true about pathogenic mosquitoes?
questions.solution:
Aedes and Anopheles lay eggs singly.

Culex lays eggs in rafts and Mansonia lays eggs in star-shaped clusters.

Anopheles has spotted wings while the other pathogenic species have unspotted wings.

Aedes transmits yellow fever, dengue and chikungunya. Culex is the main vector for JE and filariasis.

questions.text: You are posted in a PHC in a coastal region as a part of your rural postings. Which of the following Anopheles species is most commonly found here?
questions.solution:
Anopheles stephensi and Anopheles sundaicus are found in coastal regions.

Anopheles stephensi is also the main vector of malaria in urban regions. Anopheles culicifacies and Anopheles philippinensis are found in the plains. Anopheles fluviatilis and Anopheles minimus are found in foot-hill regions.

questions.text: Which of the following species of Anopheles mosquitoes transmits urban malaria?
questions.solution: Urban malaria is transmitted by Anopheles stephensi.

questions.text: What is the distance around an airport or seaport that has to be kept free of all mosquitoes?
questions.solution: The distance around an airport or seaport that has to be kept free of all mosquitoes is 400 metres. This helps in limiting the spread of vector-borne diseases to new geographic regions.

questions.text: Identify the following vector.
questions.solution:
The given image is of a housefly, whose scientific name is Musca domestica.

Related Pearl: Arthropod- borne diseases

Arthropod Disease transmitted
Anopheles mosquito Malaria, Filariasis
Culex mosquito Bancroftian filariasis, Japenese encephalitis, West nile fever, Viral arthritis
Aedes mosquito Yellow fever, Dengue, Chikungunya, filariasis, zika
Mansoni Mosquito Filariasis, Chikungunya

questions.text: Which of the following is not a  method of disease transmission by houseflies?
questions.solution:
Houseflies do not transmit diseases by biting. They transmit diseases by mechanical transmission by their legs or feet, vomit drop, and defecation.

They transmit a variety of diseases like:

  • Typhoid
  • Polio
  • Dysentery
  • Amoebiasis
  • Anthrax
  • Yaws

questions.text: Which disease is transmitted by the  following vector that is found in cracks and crevices of walls in the day time?
questions.solution:
The given image is of a sandfly. It transmits visceral leishmaniasis.

Note: Sandfly acts as a vector for the following diseases:

  • Kala-azar
  • Oriental sore
  • Sandfly fever
  • Oroya fever

Japanese encephalitis is transmitted by the Culex mosquito. Dengue is transmitted by the Aedes mosquito.

Trypanosomiasis is transmitted by the tsetse fly.

Related Pearl: Sandfly

  • They are also referred to as Phlebotomus.
  • They transmit diseases such as kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), Oriental sore, sandfly fever, and Oroya fever.
  • They are generally smaller than mosquitoes and are hairy insects.
  • They like to dwell in cracks and crevices in walls during the daytime. They are active during the night (nocturnal pests).
  • They do not fly for more than 50 yards.
  • They can be controlled by insecticides and also by proper sanitation.

questions.text: Sandfly does not transmit:
questions.solution:
Trench fever is not transmitted by sandflies. It is transmitted by lice and caused by Bartonella quintana.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is transmitted by the vector shown in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The vector shown in the image is a tsetse fly.It transmitsAfrican sleeping sickness (African human trypanosomiasis).

Tsetse flies belong to the genusGlossina. Theyhave not demonstrated insecticide resistance.Methods of tsetse fly control include spraying of DDT, clearing of vegetation, destruction of wild game and genetic control.

questions.text: A patient presents with blurring of vision and a painless swelling over his left elbow which has gradually been increasing in size over the past 1 year. On examination, he is noted to have patchy depigmentation on his legs. Which of the following vectors transmits the disease he's suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of onchocerciasis, also known as river blindness. It is transmitted by blackfly.

The usual presentation of onchocerciasis is the formation of a subcutaneous nodule or onchocercoma. It is a firm non-tender nodule arising from bony sites like the scalp, elbow, ribs, and iliac crest. It is associated with pruritus and rashes. Patients also present with patchy depigmentation on the legs called leopard skin.

The presence of microfilaria in the eye causes photophobia and gradual loss of vision. The most severe manifestations are sclerosing keratitis and chorioretinitis which can lead to blindness.

Blackfly is also called Simulium. It has a flight range of almost 100 miles, making control of adult flies difficult. Abate is widely used as a larvicidal insecticide. The image given below shows a blackfly.

questions.text: Spot the wrongly matched arthropod and disease.
questions.solution:
Blackflies (Simulium) are the vector for onchocerciasis and not Chaga's disease.

An arthropod or an invertebrate that transmits infection is called a vector. It transmits infection by:

  • Inoculation into or through the skin or mucous membrane
  • Biting
  • Deposit of infective materials on skin or food or other objects

Note: Chagas disease is transmitted by the reduviid bugs or kissing bugs or triatomines.
